panels.description: Apdex is a measure of requests that complete within a tolerable period of time for the service. Higher is better.

1h Outage SLO (2% of monthly error budget)

panels.title: git Service Apdex

targets.expr:
sum(
  label_replace(
    vector(0) and on() (gitlab_service_apdex:ratio_1h{env="$environment",environment="$environment",monitor="global",stage="$stage",type="git"}),
    "period", "na", "", ""
  )
  or
  label_replace(
    vector(1) and on () (gitlab_service_apdex:ratio_5m{env="$environment",environment="$environment",monitor="global",stage="$stage",type="git"} < on(tier, type) group_left() (1 - (14.4 * (1 - slo:min:events:gitlab_service_apdex:ratio{monitor="global",type="git"})))),
    "period", "5m", "", ""
  )
  or
  label_replace(
    vector(2) and on () (gitlab_service_apdex:ratio_1h{env="$environment",environment="$environment",monitor="global",stage="$stage",type="git"} < on(tier, type) group_left() (1 - (14.4 * (1 - slo:min:events:gitlab_service_apdex:ratio{monitor="global",type="git"})))),
    "period", "1h", "", ""
  )
  or
  label_replace(
    vector(4) and on () (gitlab_service_apdex:ratio_30m{env="$environment",environment="$environment",monitor="global",stage="$stage",type="git"} < on(tier, type) group_left() (1 - (6 * (1 - slo:min:events:gitlab_service_apdex:ratio{monitor="global",type="git"})))),
    "period", "30m", "", ""
  )
  or
  label_replace(
    vector(8) and on () (gitlab_service_apdex:ratio_6h{env="$environment",environment="$environment",monitor="global",stage="$stage",type="git"} < on(tier, type) group_left() (1 - (6 * (1 - slo:min:events:gitlab_service_apdex:ratio{monitor="global",type="git"})))),
    "period", "6h", "", ""
  )
)

panels.content:
### Description

We monitor GitLab shell, using HAProxy SSH connection information.



### Observability Tools

* [üìñ Kibana: GitLab Shell logs](https://log.gprd.gitlab.net/app/kibana#/discover?_a=(columns:!(json.command,json.msg,json.level,json.gl_project_path,json.error),filters:!((query:(match:(json.stage:(query:'$stage',type:phrase)))),(query:(match:(json.type:(query:git,type:phrase))))),index:'AWORyp9K1NBBQZg_dXA9')&_g=(time:(from:'${__from:date:iso}',to:'${__to:date:iso}')))

panels.content:
### Description

Measures aggregated HTTP request traffic through the HAProxy.
5xx responses are considered to be failures.



### Observability Tools

* [BigQuery: Top http clients by number of requests, cny stage, 10m](https://console.cloud.google.com/bigquery?project=gitlab-production&sq=805818759045:dea839bd669e41b5bc264c510294bb9f)
* [BigQuery: Top http clients by number of requests, main stage, 10m](https://console.cloud.google.com/bigquery?project=gitlab-production&sq=805818759045:704c6bdf00a743d195d344306bf207ee)

panels.content:
### Description

Measures aggregated L4 traffic through the HAProxy. Traffic is measured in TCP connections,
with upstream TCP connection failures being treated as service-level failures.



### Observability Tools

* [BigQuery: Top ssh clients by number of requests, 10m](https://console.cloud.google.com/bigquery?project=gitlab-production&sq=805818759045:8a185b18fafe4081bf9fbdb5354844f9)

### Observability Tools

panels.title: workhorse SLI Apdex

targets.expr:
sum(
  label_replace(
    vector(0) and on() (gitlab_component_apdex:ratio_1h{component="workhorse",env="$environment",environment="$environment",monitor="global",stage="$stage",type="git"}),
    "period", "na", "", ""
  )
  or
  label_replace(
    vector(1) and on () (gitlab_component_apdex:ratio_5m{component="workhorse",env="$environment",environment="$environment",monitor="global",stage="$stage",type="git"} < on(tier, type) group_left() (1 - (14.4 * (1 - slo:min:events:gitlab_service_apdex:ratio{monitor="global",type="git"})))),
    "period", "5m", "", ""
  )
  or
  label_replace(
    vector(2) and on () (gitlab_component_apdex:ratio_1h{component="workhorse",env="$environment",environment="$environment",monitor="global",stage="$stage",type="git"} < on(tier, type) group_left() (1 - (14.4 * (1 - slo:min:events:gitlab_service_apdex:ratio{monitor="global",type="git"})))),
    "period", "1h", "", ""
  )
  or
  label_replace(
    vector(4) and on () (gitlab_component_apdex:ratio_30m{component="workhorse",env="$environment",environment="$environment",monitor="global",stage="$stage",type="git"} < on(tier, type) group_left() (1 - (6 * (1 - slo:min:events:gitlab_service_apdex:ratio{monitor="global",type="git"})))),
    "period", "30m", "", ""
  )
  or
  label_replace(
    vector(8) and on () (gitlab_component_apdex:ratio_6h{component="workhorse",env="$environment",environment="$environment",monitor="global",stage="$stage",type="git"} < on(tier, type) group_left() (1 - (6 * (1 - slo:min:events:gitlab_service_apdex:ratio{monitor="global",type="git"})))),
    "period", "6h", "", ""
  )
)

panels.title: workhorse SLI RPS - Requests per Second

panels.content:
### Description

Monitors the Workhorse instance running in the Git fleet, via the HTTP interface. This SLI
excludes API requests, which have their own SLI with tigher latency thresholds.
Websocket connections are excluded from the apdex score.



### Observability Tools

* [Google Stackdriver Continuous Profiling](https://console.cloud.google.com/profiler;timespan=4h/workhorse-git;type=CPU/cpu?project=gitlab-production)

panels.content:
### Description

Monitors Workhorse API endpoints, running in the Git fleet, via the HTTP interface.
Workhorse API requests have much tigher latency requirements, as these requests originate in GitLab-Shell
and are on the critical path for authentication of Git SSH commands.



### Observability Tools

* [Google Stackdriver Continuous Profiling](https://console.cloud.google.com/profiler;timespan=4h/workhorse-git;type=CPU/cpu?project=gitlab-production)

panels.description:
This resource measures average CPU utilization across an all cores in a service fleet.
If it is becoming saturated, it may indicate that the fleet needs
horizontal or vertical scaling.
 Lower is better.

targets.expr:
clamp_min(
  clamp_max(
    max by(environment, tier, type, stage) (
  clamp_min(
    clamp_max(
      1 - avg by (environment, tier, type, stage) (
        rate(node_cpu_seconds_total{mode="idle", env="$environment",environment="$environment",stage="$stage",type="git"}[5m])
      )
      ,
      1)
  ,
  0)
)

  ,1)
,0)

clamp_min(
  clamp_max(
    max(
      max_over_time(
        gitlab_component_saturation:ratio{env="$environment",environment="$environment",stage="$stage",type="git", component="cpu"}[$__interval]
      )
    ) by (component)
  ,1)
,0)

panels.title: cpu component saturation: Average Service CPU Utilization

panels.description:
Disk inode utilization per device per node.

If this is too high, its possible that a directory is filling up with
files. Consider logging in an checking temp directories for large numbers
of files
 Lower is better.

targets.expr:
clamp_min(
  clamp_max(
    max by(environment, tier, type, stage, fqdn, device) (
  clamp_min(
    clamp_max(
      1 - (
        node_filesystem_files_free{fstype=~"(ext.|xfs)", env="$environment",environment="$environment",stage="$stage",type="git"}
        /
        node_filesystem_files{fstype=~"(ext.|xfs)", env="$environment",environment="$environment",stage="$stage",type="git"}
      )
      ,
      1)
  ,
  0)
)

  ,1)
,0)

clamp_min(
  clamp_max(
    max(
      max_over_time(
        gitlab_component_saturation:ratio{env="$environment",environment="$environment",stage="$stage",type="git", component="disk_inodes"}[$__interval]
      )
    ) by (component)
  ,1)
,0)

panels.description:
Kubernetes containers are allocated a share of CPU. When this is exhausted, the container may be thottled.
 Lower is better.

targets.expr:
clamp_min(
  clamp_max(
    max by(environment, tier, type, stage, pod, container) (
  clamp_min(
    clamp_max(
      sum by (environment, tier, type, stage, pod, container) (
        rate(container_cpu_usage_seconds_total:labeled{container!="", container!="POD", env="$environment",environment="$environment",stage="$stage",type="git"}[5m])
      )
      /
      sum by(environment, tier, type, stage, pod, container) (
        container_spec_cpu_quota:labeled{container!="", container!="POD", env="$environment",environment="$environment",stage="$stage",type="git"}
        /
        container_spec_cpu_period:labeled{container!="", container!="POD", env="$environment",environment="$environment",stage="$stage",type="git"}
      )
      ,
      1)
  ,
  0)
)

  ,1)
,0)

panels.title: kube_container_cpu component saturation: Kube Container CPU Utilization

panels.description:
Records the total memory utilization for containers for this service, as a percentage of
the memory limit as configured through Kubernetes.
 Lower is better.

targets.expr:
clamp_min(
  clamp_max(
    max by(environment, tier, type, stage, pod, container) (
  clamp_min(
    clamp_max(
      container_memory_working_set_bytes:labeled{container!="", container!="POD", env="$environment",environment="$environment",stage="$stage",type="git"}
      /
      (container_spec_memory_limit_bytes:labeled{container!="", container!="POD", env="$environment",environment="$environment",stage="$stage",type="git"} > 0)
      ,
      1)
  ,
  0)
)

  ,1)
,0)

panels.title: kube_container_memory component saturation: Kube Container Memory Utilization

panels.description:
The HPA is the [Horizontal Pod Autoscaler](https://kubernetes.io/docs/tasks/run-application/horizontal-pod-autoscale/).
It automatically scales the number of Pods in a deployment based on metrics.

The HPA has a configured upper maximum. When this limit is reached, the HPA will not increase the number of pods and
other resource saturation (eg, CPU, memory) may occur.
 Lower is better.

targets.expr:
clamp_min(
  clamp_max(
    max by(environment, tier, type, stage, hpa, shard) (
  clamp_min(
    clamp_max(
      kube_hpa_status_desired_replicas:labeled{env="$environment",environment="$environment",stage="$stage",type="git", shard!~"database-throttled|elasticsearch|gitaly-throttled|memory-bound|urgent-other"}
      /
      kube_hpa_spec_max_replicas:labeled{env="$environment",environment="$environment",stage="$stage",type="git", shard!~"database-throttled|elasticsearch|gitaly-throttled|memory-bound|urgent-other"}
      ,
      1)
  ,
  0)
)

  ,1)
,0)

panels.title: memory component saturation: Memory Utilization per Node

panels.description:
Netfilter connection tracking table utilization per node.

When saturated, new connection attempts (incoming SYN packets) are dropped with no reply, leaving clients to slowly retry (and typically fail again) over the next several seconds.  When packets are being dropped due to this condition, kernel will log the event as: "nf_conntrack: table full, dropping packet".
 Lower is better.

targets.expr:
clamp_min(
  clamp_max(
    max by(environment, tier, type, stage, fqdn, instance) (
  clamp_min(
    clamp_max(
      max_over_time(node_nf_conntrack_entries{env="$environment",environment="$environment",stage="$stage",type="git"}[1m])
      /
      node_nf_conntrack_entries_limit{env="$environment",environment="$environment",stage="$stage",type="git"}
      ,
      1)
  ,
  0)
)

  ,1)
,0)

panels.title: nf_conntrack_entries component saturation: conntrack Entries per Node

panels.description:
Measures the amount of scheduler waiting time that processes are waiting
to be scheduled, according to [`CPU Scheduling Metrics`](https://www.robustperception.io/cpu-scheduling-metrics-from-the-node-exporter).

A high value indicates that a node has more processes to be run than CPU time available
to handle them, and may lead to degraded responsiveness and performance from the application.

Additionally, it may indicate that the fleet is under-provisioned.
 Lower is better.

targets.expr:
clamp_min(
  clamp_max(
    max by(environment, tier, type, stage, fqdn, shard) (
  clamp_min(
    clamp_max(
      avg without (cpu) (rate(node_schedstat_waiting_seconds_total{env="$environment",environment="$environment",stage="$stage",type="git"}[1h]))
      ,
      1)
  ,
  0)
)

  ,1)
,0)

panels.title: node_schedstat_waiting component saturation: Node Scheduler Waiting Time

panels.description:
Open file descriptor utilization per instance.

Saturation on file descriptor limits may indicate a resource-descriptor leak in the application.

As a temporary fix, you may want to consider restarting the affected process.
 Lower is better.

targets.expr:
clamp_min(
  clamp_max(
    max(
      max_over_time(
        gitlab_component_saturation:ratio{env="$environment",environment="$environment",stage="$stage",type="git", component="open_fds"}[$__interval]
      )
    ) by (component)
  ,1)
,0)

panels.title: open_fds component saturation: Open file descriptor utilization per instance

panels.description:
Rails uses connection pools for its database connections. As each
node may have multiple connection pools, this is by node and by
database host.

Read more about this resource in our [documentation](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/database/client_side_connection_pool.html#client-side-connection-pool).

If this resource is saturated, it may indicate that our connection
pools are not correctly sized, perhaps because an unexpected
application thread is using a database connection.
 Lower is better.

targets.expr:
clamp_min(
  clamp_max(
    max by(environment, tier, type, stage, instance, host, port) (
  clamp_min(
    clamp_max(
      (
        avg_over_time(gitlab_database_connection_pool_busy{class="ActiveRecord::Base", env="$environment",environment="$environment",stage="$stage",type="git"}[5m])
        +
        avg_over_time(gitlab_database_connection_pool_dead{class="ActiveRecord::Base", env="$environment",environment="$environment",stage="$stage",type="git"}[5m])
      )
      /
      gitlab_database_connection_pool_size{class="ActiveRecord::Base", env="$environment",environment="$environment",stage="$stage",type="git"}
      ,
      1)
  ,
  0)
)

  ,1)
,0)

panels.title: rails_db_connection_pool component saturation: Rails DB Connection Pool Utilization

panels.description:
Ruby (technically Ruby MRI), like some other scripting languages, uses a Global VM lock (GVL) also known as a
Global Interpreter Lock (GIL) to ensure that multiple threads can execute safely. Ruby code is only allowed to
execute in one thread in a process at a time. When calling out to c extensions, the thread can cede the lock to
other thread while it continues to execute.

This means that when CPU-bound workloads run in a multithreaded environment such as Puma or Sidekiq, contention
with other Ruby worker threads running in the same process can occur, effectively slowing thoses threads down as
they await GVL entry.

Often the best fix for this situation is to add more workers by scaling up the fleet.
 Lower is better.

targets.expr:
clamp_min(
  clamp_max(
    max by(environment, tier, type, stage, fqdn, pod) (
  clamp_min(
    clamp_max(
      rate(ruby_process_cpu_seconds_total{env="$environment",environment="$environment",stage="$stage",type="git"}[10m])
      ,
      1)
  ,
  0)
)

  ,1)
,0)

panels.title: ruby_thread_contention component saturation: Ruby Thread Contention

clamp_min(

clamp_min(
  clamp_max(
    max(
      max_over_time(
        gitlab_component_saturation:ratio{env="$environment",environment="$environment",stage="$stage",type="git", component="single_node_cpu"}[$__interval]
      )
    ) by (component)
  ,1)
,0)

panels.title: single_node_cpu component saturation: Average CPU Utilization per Node

panels.description:
Puma thread utilization per node.

Puma uses a fixed size thread pool to handle HTTP requests. This metric shows how many threads are busy handling requests. When this resource is saturated,
we will see puma queuing taking place. Leading to slowdowns across the application.

Puma saturation is usually caused by latency problems in downstream services: usually Gitaly or Postgres, but possibly also Redis.
Puma saturation can also be caused by traffic spikes.
 Lower is better.

targets.expr:
clamp_min(
  clamp_max(
    max by(environment, tier, type, stage, fqdn) (
  clamp_min(
    clamp_max(
      sum by(environment, tier, type, stage, fqdn) (avg_over_time(instance:puma_active_connections:sum{env="$environment",environment="$environment",stage="$stage",type="git"}[1m]))
      /
      sum by(environment, tier, type, stage, fqdn) (instance:puma_max_threads:sum{env="$environment",environment="$environment",stage="$stage",type="git"})
      ,
      1)
  ,
  0)
)

  ,1)
,0)

targets.expr:
clamp_min(
  clamp_max(
    max(
      gitlab_component_saturation:ratio:avg_over_time_1w{
        type="git",
        environment="$environment",
        stage=~"$stage|"
      }
    ) by (component)
  ,1)
,0)
